item.description:
This discussion touches on what I view as the essence of ethics. What matters, good will and intention or the acts and consequences that follow from them? Any ethical theory must grapple with the dilemmas that can develop between these basic perspectives. The problem may be encapsulated by the famous saying that “The road to Hell is paved with good intentions!” But if this saying is the whole story, then so much for intentions; but is it?

Are you a utilitarian in which the utilities of actions are all that matter? Or are you a Kantian in which a “good will” is structured by a fiction that Kant invented called the “categorical imperative?” Or is the form of intention known as compassion (Schopenhauer) the true basis of morality? Or is Nietzsche’s “will to power” the real deal, in which case intention (will) but also consequences are key because what good are consequences without power. Buddhistic mindfulness and American pragmatism are other perspectives on this critical issue, and there are many more.

Clearly, both intentions and their consequences are vital, but which is more vital? And what needs to be done or can anything be done to make ethics more relevant, and what role could  conceptualizations of good intentions and consequences play in making ethics more relevant and applicable? I tend to think that intentionality is the more critical component of ethical conceptualizations of morality, and I go into detail on this matter in a nearly finished book (the writing of which will be completed before the end of the year). So I am eager to get your take on the question of ethical intentions and their consequences.
